#Text=Scratch a Dog 's Belly
#Text=If you 've been around a dog , chances are you 've scratched a dog 's stomach .
#Text=Most dogs love a good belly rub and will actively seek one out from people they trust .
#Text=However , not all dogs are comfortable with belly rubs and you should respect the ones that are n't .
#Text=By learning what to look for before rubbing a dog 's stomach , you can keep your furry friend happy .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Learning If Your Dog Wants a Belly Rub
#Text=Look for signs that your dog wants a belly rub .
#Text=Most dogs want their stomachs scratched or rubbed and it 's generally fine to do so .
#Text=However , some dogs are not comfortable with this and you will have to look for the signs that your dog is happy to have its belly rubbed before doing so .
#Text=A dog will lie down , presenting its stomach and wagging its tail to show it 's comfortable with you .
#Text=Your dog should look relaxed and will lay down without tension in its body .
#Text=A dog looking for a belly scratch may roll around playfully on its back .
#Text=Presenting its stomach can be a sign of trust from your dog .
#Text=Look for signs of submissive or nervous behavior .
#Text=Some dogs will present their stomach out of fear or submission .
#Text=These dogs do not actually want their stomachs rubbed and you should avoid doing so .
#Text=Look for some of the following signs of submission and fear in your dog and avoid rubbing its stomach if they are present .
#Text=Dogs who are afraid will often tuck its tail in between its legs .
#Text=Nervous dogs will take on a hunched and tense posture .
#Text=Fearful dogs will likely not move much after they present its stomach .
#Text=Submissive and fearful dogs may growl at you if you approach them .
#Text=Do n't force a belly rub .
#Text=If your dog appears uncomfortable or you are unsure about your dog 's level of comfort you should avoid scratching its stomach .
#Text=Forcing an uncomfortable dog to allow you to scratch its stomach can cause unneeded stress for the dog and can even result in it biting you .
#Text=Never try to flip your dog on its back to rub its stomach .
#Text=Always allow your dog to present its stomach on its own .
#Text=Forcing a belly rub can make your dog mistrust you .
#Text=Scratching Your Dog 's Stomach
#Text=Wait for your dog to present its stomach .
#Text=Before you can scratch your dog 's stomach you will need to wait for it to show its stomach to you .
#Text=While you could try to make it roll over , forcing the belly rub is not a good idea .
#Text=Play with your dog and calmly wait for it to show you its stomach for scratching .
#Text=Always wait for your dog to show its stomach .
#Text=You dog will naturally roll over and present its stomach if it wants a belly rub .
#Text=A dog who wants a belly rub will appear loose and relaxed in regards to its body language .
#Text=Rub or scratch the dog 's stomach . After your dog has presented its stomach and you feel that it is comfortable and relaxed , you can begin to rub its belly .
#Text=As you rub the dog 's stomach keep an eye on its behavior , looking for signs of enjoyment or discomfort .
#Text=It 's normal for some areas of the stomach to cause your dog to kick when you scratch them .
#Text=Always scratch or rub gently as the stomach is a sensitive area on a dog .
#Text=Feel free to rub your dog 's stomach however you 'd like .
#Text=Try rubbing in circles , short scratches , or longer motions up and down the whole length of your dog 's stomach .
#Text=Stop when you are done or your dog becomes uncomfortable .
#Text=After you have scratched your dog 's stomach for a while you may decide it 's time to stop .
#Text=Your dog may try to get more belly rubs out of you and it 's fine to continue if you want .
#Text=However , if your dog tries to get up or move away from you it is time to stop .
#Text=If you stop rubbing and your dog moves away from you , it 's time to stop scratching its stomach .
#Text=Feel free to stop scratching your dog 's stomach any time you wish .
#Text=Scratch or rub other areas on your dog .
#Text=Although dogs love a good belly rub , they also enjoy receiving attention on other areas of their bodies .
#Text=Try petting , patting , rubbing , or scratching some other places on your dog to see what they might enjoy .
#Text=As always , work slowly , touch gently , and make sure your dog is truly enjoying it .
#Text=Your dog might enjoy a rub or scratch under or around its ears .
#Text=Most dogs will like a good neck rub or scratch .
#Text=A dog might enjoy it when you scratch its chest .
#Text=Try scratching under your dog 's chin .
#Text=A dog might like it when you scratch the area of its back just above where its tail starts .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Always be gentle with your dog , especially if it is a small breed .
#Text=Stop immediately if your dog growls or appears to be in pain when you are rubbing its belly .
#Text=Never force a stomach scratch .
#Text=Make sure your dog is comfortable with a belly rub before doing so .
#Text=Quick Summary
